column4: is there a way to stop automounting under ~/.gvfs and mount under /mnt instead? annoying to try and access files in mounted filesystems when all mounted filesystems are under a hidden directory.
you shouldn't be manipulating .gvfs manually
Why not?
it's a virtual filesystem
so I should scrap it and just use smbmount / nfs whatever if I actually want to really use it like a real filesystem and .gvfs is just there for pose value?
what exactly are you doing that makes you think you need to be using .gvfs

I have a codebase under windows on a vm that I want to edit files on and keep under RCS with git, so I just use the VM to run IIS and otherwise forget about it, and run jEdit / git on my linux desktop to actually do work.
so use samba
it seems work fine when I just cd into the directories under .gvfs and treat it like a real filesystem, like I was able to git init git add git commit and also jedit all my source files.
why does "connect to server" use gvfs if it's a better idea to use samba?
why not just run git on windows and remote branch?  pretty offtopic but whatever
cause then I'd actually have to use windows to do the RCS instead of what I do now which is just run the server in the background and just use it as a server only and otherwise forget about it.
it isn't a better idea.  gnome needs a way to dynamically create mounts to display to a user in nautilus, and so it uses a hidden directory called .gvfs for that purpose.
So in what sense is an smb filesystem mounted under ~/.gvfs/ via fuse.gvfs different to an smb filesystem mounted using smbmount under /mnt? different drivers?
one, it's fuse, two, it's permissions are different, 3 it's non-persistent

Non persistent? ... if you make changes to the filesystem while it's mounted under fuse, they persist after unmounting, so I can only assume you mean you have to remount it every reboot or something manually?
if you restart gnome it's gone
the mount that is
right.  It has to get mounted somewhere so that gnome programs can manipulate the mounted files.  Gnome handles the mounting for you
OK, so can I tell gnome to mount it somewhere else?
if you want to handle the mounting yourself, use the standard mechanisms (mount, smbmount, fstab, etc)
no idea, i don't use gnome
